comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: The Gorman's Medical Hall store caught my eye first, so thanks for highlighting the World War I poster. We've been going through our WWI holdings lately in preparation for the centennial. Maybe we could compare notes? -- Helena (LOC)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress] And you have this poster too! Absolutely to the comparing of notes.  Carol (NLI)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
Hi Carol,
              I always thought that the L&N was the London & Newcastle Tea Company of the UK that was geographically  located in the South/South Eastern part of the Republic of Ireland, which is what I thought that shop was beside the Chemist?
Am I wrong in thinking they are one and the same as L&N.W. Midland?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] Afternoon Ken. This shop/office is definitely a railway company outlet. Thinking L & NW Midland was London & North West Midland? And L & Y Railways may have been Lancashire & Yorkshire Railway, as there's a huge picture of Blackpool in the window also. But either way, think we're talking trains rather than tea, because the other poster is advertising "Special Services" between England and Ireland via Holyhead - in fact that was a Christmas 1914 poster that probably should have been taken down by 5 January...

And oddly enough, have had a search for images of an L & N shop in Waterford, but can't find any by title, unless the shops are just incidentally in photos. But there were L & Ns on the Quays, and in Ballybricken, I think...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 
Tks for that Carol. You make a lot of sense in your Observation. 
As for the L&N's, not sure about Ballybricken, they has a warehouse on the Cork Road in the 1980's, (not a huge distance from Ballybricken), but they had a small store on the 'North side' of the river, FERRYBANK I think it was called, which closed in the 80's I think due to various local competition and changes in demography.
They had one called the ' L&N Hypermarket' on the 'Southside' of the river which this particular one has been taken over by Musgraves/Supervalu.
My own information comes from being a Sales rep in the 80's  and unfortunately never thought to take any photos of the stores I called in to.
Thanks for all that info  Carol though, very interesting.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] You're welcome! And for all of yours re L & N.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
